author: bridge-bot
content:
<KamilChNethermind> @kevaundray Did two Geth branches:
1. With GO Implementation improvements
2. With 1 + Switch Lib to GMP

Seems like 1 (GO) help quite a bit with One Cacheable scenario from Guido and generally feels like giving about 5% improvement to some worse cases (which are below 65 bits in exponent). Some results on table one - biggest improvement at 56%. No regression here, only better results.

GMP switch (2) seems like give HUGE boost in general (seems like from 70 up to 400% better results for all our modexp scenarios).
Current worst case with it is at 23.3 MGas/s (NOTE - it is different, weaker hardware than used on main dashboard so numbers may be even better).

One thing is that there seems to be some sort of regression for Cachable guido scenario (From 547 to 23.7 Mgas/s - need to be checked) and scenario called "Modexp5461base1024UNCACHABLE2" - from 111 to 67.3 MGas/s.
Do not know these scenarios so need to spend some time analyzing those, can give bytecodes for it and maybe need to wait for Marcin to give some insights.

*TL;DR:*
GO tweak improves Geth perf just a little bit.
GMP gives huge up to 5x improvement and bumping worst case scenario on Pectra spec from *13.5 to 23.5 MGas/s* but comes with some regression which needs to be analyzed.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<KamilChNethermind> Data collected here
https://grafana.observability.ethpandaops.io/d/feo4ronhsqv40h/opcodes-benchmarking-github-action?orgId=1&from=2025-07-11T09:41:32.537Z&to=2025-07-11T09:52:04.160Z&timezone=browser&var-posgreSQL=benuragv7iuwwb&var-ClientName=$__all&var-TestTitle=$__all&refresh=auto

Is running on GH agents so are weaker than commonly used machines.

@vdWijden @kevaundray If you will decide to give it a shot in Geth more official way, amke sure to tackle that regression on GMP first and then push the changes to "performance" and "performance-modexp" branches.

author: bridge-bot
content: <KamilChNethermind> Note one of these is marked as CACHABLE - and we use master branch from geth which may have precomiples caching enabled so maybe have some sort of collision with it?

author: bridge-bot
content: <vdWijden> No we have no precompile caching

author: bridge-bot
content:
<KamilChNethermind> And one more update from Nethermind team

@rubenbu did a swap of library in Nethermind from eth_pairings to mcl 
Seems like EC mul/add/pairing scenarios are nicely improved (at least 10% but there are scenarios improved by 40 up to 250%)

Now our worst case for EC operations is up from 32.3 (ECMul) to 47.6 (ECPairing). ðŸ”¥

author: bridge-bot
content:
<KamilChNethermind> re: **@KamilChNethermind**
> @kevaundray Did two Geth branches:
1. With GO Implementation improvements
2. With 1 + Switch Lib to GMP

Seems like 1 (GO) help quite a bit with One Cacheable scenario from Guido and generally feels like giving about 5% improvement to some worse cases (which are below 65 bits in exponent). Some results on table one - biggest improvement at 56%. No regression here, only better results.

GMP switch (2) seems like give HUGE boost in general (seems like from 70 up to 400% better results for all our modexp scenarios).
Current worst case with it is at 23.3 MGas/s (NOTE - it is different, weaker hardware than used on main dashboard so numbers may be even better).

One thing is that there seems to be some sort of regression for Cachable guido scenario (From 547 to 23.7 Mgas/s - need to be checked) and scenario called "Modexp5461base1024UNCACHABLE2" - from 111 to 67.3 MGas/s.
Do not know these scenarios so need to spend some time analyzing those, can give bytecodes for it and maybe need to wait for Marcin to give some insights.

TL;DR:
GO tweak improves Geth perf just a little bit.
GMP gives huge up to 5x improvement and bumping worst case scenario on Pectra spec from 13.5 to 23.5 MGas/s but comes with some regression which needs to be analyzed.
New version from Kev fixed the biggest regression.
The second scenario seems like is actually some bottleneck in GMP - without performs around 110Mgas, after around 70 and seems like nethermind/reth also have around 70 for this scenario. So we need to dig a little bit into that direction as may be unexplored ground for modexp.

This precompile just keeps on giving...
